site_name: Out of Africa Wildlife Park, LLC

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The program of veterinary care states that all birds that have no history of vaccine status, be vaccinated for West Nile
Virus. No vaccine records are available for review for any birds and the facility representative states the animals have not
been vaccinated for West Nile Virus.
In addition, the program of veterinary care for dogs states that Bordetella vaccine be given annually and there is no record
of this vaccine for "Alaska" and "Guardian" that are 2 adult wolf hybrids.
Failure to follow the program of veterinary care set by the attending veterinarian may result in illness or injury to animals.
Exhibitors shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the appropriate methods to prevent, control
and treat diseases and injuries.
Correct by 16 August 2024.

There is no written exercise plan available for review at time of inspection. Exercise for dogs is critical for overall health
and psychological well-being. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an
appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In addition, the plan must be approved by the attending
veterinarian. The plan must include written standard procedures to be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise.
Correct by 12 August 2024.

There is no record that the 2 wolf hybrids "Alaska" and "Guardian" have had a complete head to tail physical exam by the
attending veterinarian in the past year. Physical examinations by the attending veterinarian are important to evaluate the
overall health and physical body condition of the dogs in the facility. In addition, physical exams help the attending
veterinarian evaluate chronic medical conditions, make changes to treatment and catch changes in health status. All dogs
must have a complete head to tail physical examination by the attending veterinarian that occurs not less than once every
12 months.
Correct by 16 August 2024.

Annual heartworm and intestinal parasite testing is set in the program of veterinary care for dogs, but parasite testing has
been greater than a year since it has been conducted for 2 wolf hybrids "Alaska" and "Guardian". Internal parasites such
as coccidia, giardia, and heartworms are common causes of disease in dogs and if left undetected and not properly
treated, can lead to serious illness. Correct by ensuring all required information listed in section 3.13(a)(3) is included in
the program of veterinary care in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian and that the
program is followed.
Correct by 16 August 2024.

Multiple electrical cords for a heating element are connected to an outdoor power outlet and are laying on the ground of
the outdoor primary enclosure for 2 adult Brown Lemurs. The outdoor ambient temperature within the enclosure was
97.6F according to the Kestral instrument used by the inspector. A facility representative stated the heating element is not
in use and unplugged the cords during inspection. The facility representative also stated the cords would be removed
from the enclosure later that day. Failure to maintain structurally sound housing facilities for nonhuman primates that
protect them from injury, such as having powered electrical cords within reach, may result in adverse events such as
electrocution or strangulation. Exhibitors must design and construct housing facilities that are structurally sound for the
species of nonhuman primates housed and protect them from injury.
Correct by 5 August 2024.

Sharp points are present in the outdoor primary enclosure for "Apache", a Scarlet Macaw. Multiple metal wires are
hanging from the roof of the sheltered perch in the middle of the enclosure. One wire appears to be a broken piece of wire
to secure the roof to the post. The other two wires appear to be part of a holding system meant for a lamp fixture. Sharp
points and edges may cause injury to the animal. The primary enclosure must be kept in good repair and have no sharp
points or edges that could injure the bird.
Correct by 12 August 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The program of veterinary care states that all birds that have no history of vaccine status, be vaccinated for West Nile 
Virus. No vaccine records are available for review for any birds and the facility representative states the animals have not 
been vaccinated for West Nile Virus.  
 
In addition, the program of veterinary care for dogs states that Bordetella vaccine be given annually and there is no record 
of this vaccine for "Alaska" and "Guardian" that are 2 adult wolf hybrids. 
 
Failure to follow the program of veterinary care set by the attending veterinarian may result in illness or injury to animals. 
Exhibitors shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the appropriate methods to prevent, control 
and treat diseases and injuries.  
 
Correct by 16 August 2024. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
There is no written exercise plan available for review at time of inspection. Exercise for dogs is critical for overall health 
and psychological well-being. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an 
appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In addition, the plan must be approved by the attending 
veterinarian. The plan must include written standard procedures to be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise. 
 
Correct by 12 August 2024. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There is no record that the 2 wolf hybrids "Alaska" and "Guardian" have had a complete head to tail physical exam by the 
attending veterinarian in the past year. Physical examinations by the attending veterinarian are important to evaluate the 
overall health and physical body condition of the dogs in the facility. In addition, physical exams help the attending

veterinarian evaluate chronic medical conditions, make changes to treatment and catch changes in health status. All dogs 
must have a complete head to tail physical examination by the attending veterinarian that occurs not less than once every 
12 months.  
 
Correct by 16 August 2024. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Annual heartworm and intestinal parasite testing is set in the program of veterinary care for dogs, but parasite testing has 
been greater than a year since it has been conducted for 2 wolf hybrids "Alaska" and "Guardian". Internal parasites such 
as coccidia, giardia, and heartworms are common causes of disease in dogs and if left undetected and not properly 
treated, can lead to serious illness. Correct by ensuring all required information listed in section 3.13(a)(3) is included in 
the program of veterinary care in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian and that the 
program is followed. 
 
Correct by 16 August 2024. 
3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Multiple electrical cords for a heating element are connected to an outdoor power outlet and are laying on the ground of 
the outdoor primary enclosure for 2 adult Brown Lemurs. The outdoor ambient temperature within the enclosure was 
97.6F according to the Kestral instrument used by the inspector. A facility representative stated the heating element is not 
in use and unplugged the cords during inspection. The facility representative also stated the cords would be removed 
from the enclosure later that day. Failure to maintain structurally sound housing facilities for nonhuman primates that 
protect them from injury, such as having powered electrical cords within reach, may result in adverse events such as 
electrocution or strangulation. Exhibitors must design and construct housing facilities that are structurally sound for the 
species of nonhuman primates housed and protect them from injury. 
 
Correct by 5 August 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Sharp points are present in the outdoor primary enclosure for "Apache", a Scarlet Macaw. Multiple metal wires are 
hanging from the roof of the sheltered perch in the middle of the enclosure. One wire appears to be a broken piece of wire 
to secure the roof to the post. The other two wires appear to be part of a holding system meant for a lamp fixture. Sharp 
points and edges may cause injury to the animal. The primary enclosure must be kept in good repair and have no sharp 
points or edges that could injure the bird. 
 
Correct by 12 August 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
